summary: J. C. King was the Chief of the Western Hemisphere (WH) Division within the CIA. A memorandum from J.C. King to the Deputy Director (Plans) requests approval for the revised Related Mission Directive for Mexico, which outlines objectives related to countering communism and maintaining friendly relations with the Mexican government. The documents suggest King's involvement in overseeing CIA operations and policies within the Western Hemisphere, particularly concerning Cuba and Mexico. He appears to have been in a position to authorize and manage projects, as well as to communicate with high-ranking officials within the CIA regarding strategic objectives.
significance: J. C. King's significance in the JFK context stems from his role as Chief of the WH Division, which placed him in a position to oversee CIA activities in regions relevant to the assassination, such as Cuba and Mexico. While the documents do not directly link him to the assassination, his involvement in covert operations, particularly those targeting Fidel Castro and countering communism in Latin America, could be relevant to understanding the broader context of the events surrounding JFK's death. His approval of the Related Mission Directive for Mexico and his oversight of projects like LIFEAT indicate his influence in shaping CIA policy and operations in the region.
